Fire Progression¶

wxee is designed for processing weather data, but it can also be useful for remote sensing data. In this example, we’ll look at how wxee can work with data from the GOES-R sensors to visualize fire progressions over time.

Setup¶

[1]:

import ee
import wxee

ee.Initialize()

Downloading Data to xarray¶

GOES-16 captures 5-minute interval data including a mask with codes identifying fire hotspot detections. We’ll select a time window that experienced explosive fire growth in the Western Cascades of Oregon, USA.

[2]:

ts = wxee.TimeSeries("NOAA/GOES/16/FDCC").select("Mask").filterDate("2020-09-08", "2020-09-09")
ts.describe("minute")

NOAA/GOES/16/FDCC
        Images: 288
        Start date: 2020-09-08 00:01:16 UTC
        End date: 2020-09-08 23:56:16 UTC
        Mean interval: 5.00 minutes

Before we go any further, we need to convert the mask codes to a binary mask of fire presence. Values 10, 11, 30, and 31 represent maximum confidence fire detections, so we’ll set those pixels to 1 and all other pixels to 0 in all images.

[3]:

def fire_mask(img):
    mask = ee.Image(0).rename("fire")
    mask = (mask
        .where(img.eq(10), 1)
        .where(img.eq(11), 1)
        .where(img.eq(30), 1)
        .where(img.eq(31), 1)
    )
    # Copy the properties from the original images to avoid losing time data.
    return mask.copyProperties(img, img.propertyNames())

# Convert each mask class image into a binary fire presence mask
fire_masks = ts.map(lambda img: fire_mask(img))

Now we can aggregate the 288 5-minute masks to 24 hourly masks. We’ll use a max reducer, meaning that an hourly hotspot was detected at least once within the hour.

[4]:

hourly_fire = fire_masks.aggregate_time("hour", reducer=ee.Reducer.max())
hourly_fire.describe("minute")

NOAA/GOES/16/FDCC
        Images: 24
        Start date: 2020-09-08 00:01:16 UTC
        End date: 2020-09-08 23:01:16 UTC
        Mean interval: 60.00 minutes

Select a region around the largest fire, Beachie Creek.

[5]:

geom = ee.Geometry.Polygon(
    [[[-122.77807114256022, 45.370803623985665],
      [-122.77807114256022, 44.519360582318896],
      [-121.46520493162272, 44.519360582318896],
      [-121.46520493162272, 45.370803623985665]]]
)

And download the data to an xarray.Dataset.

[6]:

ds = hourly_fire.wx.to_xarray(region=geom, scale=2_000, crs="EPSG:26910")

Progression Over Time¶

Now we have 35 2D arrays representing hotspot detections in each hour. First, let’s ee what those look like as a time series.

[7]:

ds.fire.plot(col="time", size=2, col_wrap=6)

[7]:

<xarray.plot.facetgrid.FacetGrid at 0x7f4932a936d0>

That shows us how the fire grew over time, but maybe we want a single summary image describing that progression. Let’s calculate the first hour that a given pixel burned. Rather than storing specific times, we’ll represent them as time elapsed since the beginning of the time series.

First, get the start time of the time series and calculate the number of hours elapsed between each time step and the start time.

[8]:

start = ds.time.min()
# Convert milliseconds to hours
delta_hours = (ds.time - start) / 3_600_000_000_000

Now, we’ll multiply the delta hours by the fire mask. Because non-fire pixels have a value of 0, this will give us a 3D array with elapsed hours since start for each hotspot pixel and values of 0 for all other pixels. We cast from a timedelta to an int to allow plotting.

[9]:

delta_hours_fire = (ds.fire * delta_hours).astype(int)

Finally, we can mask non-hotspot pixels (values of 0) and take the minimum over time to get the first time, in hours elapsed, that each pixel burned.

[10]:

first_burned = delta_hours_fire.where(delta_hours_fire != 0).min("time")

And of course, plot it!

[11]:

first_burned.plot(size=8)

[11]:

<matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh at 0x7f4923f2e9a0>
